questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic hypertensive patient comes with complaints of DOV and sometimes double vision with headaches. BP measures 150/80 mmHg. Fundoscopy finding is as below. What is the stage of disease according to Keith Wagner and Barker's classification?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stage 3 Cotton wool spots and flame-shaped haemorrhages are seen but papilloedema or macula star is not seen thus stage 3 Hypertensive retinopathy patients present high BP along with headache and retinopathy Grade 1: Mild to moderate narrowing or sclerosis of the smaller arterioles. Grade 2: Moderate to marked narrowing of the retinal arterioles; exaggeration of the light reflex; changes at the arteriovenous crossings. Grade 3: Retinal arteriolar narrowing and focal constriction, prominent arteriovenous crossing changes, retinal oedema, cotton-wool spots, flame-shaped haemorrhages. Grade 4: all the features of Grade 3 are seen, as well as papilloedema Pathogenesis - 3 factors play a role in pathogenesis Vasoconstriction Arteriosclerotic changes Increased vascular permeability Fundus changes that occur in patients with severe hypertension Clinical presentation includes changes of Retinopathy Choroidopathy Optic neuropathy

Highyeild:

Clinically hypertensive fundus changes can be described as Chronic hypertensive retinopathy Malignant /acute hypertensive retinopathy

Extraedge:

Fundus Changes : Salu’s sign: deflection of veins at A-V Crossing Bonnet sign: banking of veins distal to A-V Crossing Gunn signs: tapering of veins on either side of the crossing.

questions.text: Which of the following retinal diseases shows egg yolk lesions in the macula?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Best disease Best disease , also termed vitelliform macular dystrophy , is typically an autosomal dominant disorder , which classically presents in childhood with the striking appearance of a yellow or orange yolk-like lesion in the macula. The lesion evolves through several stages over many years, with increasing potential for adverse visual outcomes. A hallmark of the disease is a markedly abnormal electrooculogram (EOG) in all stages of progression and phenotypically normal carriers. Lesions in Best diseases are restricted to the eye. No systemic associations exist. Abnormalities in the eye result from a disorder in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

Highyeild:

Dysfunction of the protein bestrophin results in abnormal fluid and ion transport by the RPE . Lipofuscin (periodic acid-Schiff [PAS] positive accumulates within the RPE cells and in the sub-RPE space, particularly in the foveal area.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Bordet - Biedl syndrome Bardet-Biedl syndrome (BBS) is a multisystem non-motile ciliopathy primarily characterized by retinal cone-rod dystrophy, obesity and related complications, postaxial polydactyly, cognitive impairment, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and/or genitourinary malformations, and renal malformations and/or renal parenchymal. Option: B. Bassen Kornzweig syndrome Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome is caused by a defect in the MTTP gene that tells the body to create lipoproteins (molecules of fat combined with protein). The defect makes it hard for the body to properly digest fat and essential vitamins. Option: D. Gyrate atrophy Gyrate Atrophy of the choroida and the retina is a rare autosomal recessive retinal dystrophy characterized by progressive chorioretinal degeneration, early cataract formation and myopia.

Extraedge:

The RPE appears to have degenerative changes in some cases, and secondary loss of photoreceptor cells has been noted. Breakdown of RPE/Bruch's membrane can allow choroidal neovascularization to develop as a late complication.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmologist’s clinic with a history of decreased vision at night time. On General physical examination, the boy appears to be of short stature with central obesity, has polydactyly and his genitals are found to be underdeveloped. Fundus examination finding is given below. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of the fundus picture of the disease suffered by the boy?

options.label: C
options.text: Swollen optic disc with blurred margins

questions.correct_answer: C. Swollen optic disc with blurred margins
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Swollen optic disc with blurred margins The features such as short stature, central obesity, polydactyly and hypogonadism with night blindness point towards the diagnosis of Laurence-Moon-Beidl-Bardet syndrome, which is one of the syndromes associated with Retinitis Pigmentosa(RP). Retinitis pigmentosa is a diffuse retinal degenerative disease. Most common hereditary fundus dystrophy (1/5.000) Initially predominantly affecting the rod photoreceptors , with later degeneration of cones It may occur as AD AR XLR Sporadic Symptoms : Nyctalopia and dark adaptation difficulties are frequently presenting symptoms Mid-peripheral than far peripheral field loss Reduced central vision Cataract Photopsia Swollen optic disc with blurred margins is a feature of papilledema whereas in RP the optic disc is pale yellow and waxy.

Highyeild:

Signs : TRIAD OF Bone spiculate retinal pigmentation arteriolar attenuation waxy disc pallor The Macula may show Atrophy Epiretinal membrane formation Cystoid macular edema MYOPIA is common

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Attenuated arterioles are a feature of RP Option: B. Pigmentary spicule is a feature of RP

Extraedge:

Other Syndromes associated with RP include: NARP syndrome: Neuropathy, Ataxia, RP Usher syndrome: Hearing loss and RP Kearns Sayre Syndrome: Complete heart block, progressive ophthalmoplegia and RP

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with decreased vision from the right eye. He underwent cataract surgery 3 months ago for the same eye. FFA of the eye shows a ‘ flower pattern appearance’ in the macula region. Treatment modalities for the presenting symptoms are-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti- prostaglandin Decreased vision with FFA [ fundus fluorescein Angiography] showing “flower petal appearance” . The probable diagnosis is Cystoid macular edema . CME: There is a collection of fluid in the outer plexiform ( Henle’s layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina centred around the foveola. Ophthalmoscopy shows “ honeycomb appearance of macula”. It is a late postoperative complication of cataract surgery. There is a role of prostaglandin in the pathogenesis of CME .

Highyeild:

After cataract surgery, Anti- prostaglandin [ indomethacin, flurbiprofen, ketorolac ] is recommended in the prophylaxis of CME.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Anterior vitrectomy is recommended when CME with vitreous incarceration occurs. Option: B. Most cases of CME undergo spontaneous regression. Option: D. FFA: “flower pattern appearance”

Extraedge:

Anterior vitrectomy is recommended when CME with vitreous incarceration occurs.

questions.text: One can see different colours by the combination of three colours, red, blue and green. If one's eyes are weak in seeing a particular colour, the intensity of that particular colour is to be increased so that the person can see all the colours. If someone’s eye is weak to see red colour, this defect is called:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Protanopia An individual with normal colour vision is known as a trichromate . This is because the normal human eye can appreciate three primary colours (red, green and blue) due to the presence of three different types of cones, i.e., red-sensitive, green-sensitive and blue-sensitive. All colours of the spectrum can be perceived by the fusion of these three primary colours in varying proportions . (Young-Helmholtz trichromatic theory of colour vision.) In colour blindness, the mechanism to appreciate one or more primary colours is either defective (anomalous) or absent (anopia). It may be congenital or acquired.

Highyeild:

The gene for red colour present on X chr Genes for blue colour on chr 7 thus tritanopia is inherited as AD Protanopia is a complete defect in the perception of the red colour .such defect is the source of danger in certain occupations like drivers, sailors and traffic police

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Deuteranopia if the defect is green colour perception Option: C. Tritanopia if the defect is blue colour perception The most common colour blindness is Deuteranomaly Red-green Tests for colour blindness Option: D. Ishihara chart used for screening for congenital protein and deutan defects. It consists of 38 plates.

Extraedge:

Hardy and Ritter can detect all three congenital defects, especially useful in the pediatric age group consisting of 24 plates Holmgren s wool test

Solution:

Tunnel Vision Retinitis pigmentosa is the most common hereditary fundus dystrophy. It predominantly affects rod cells with subsequent cone degeneration Inheritance AR is the most common AD has the best prognosis due to rhodopsin mutation X-linked recessive has the worst prognosis and least common Symptoms: Bilateral involvement presenting during 2nd -3rd decade. questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the abrupt onset of painless loss of vision in his left eye. Over the last several years, he has noticed an increased blurring of vision; he says the blurring has made it difficult to read, but he can read better if he holds the book below or above eye level. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Fundoscopic examination shows subretinal fluid and a small haemorrhage with greyish-green discoloration in the macular area in the left eye, and multiple drusen in the right eye with retinal pigment epithelial changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's eye condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ranibizumab The patient's acute, painless, unilateral loss of central vision (central scotoma) , together with his history of gradual loss of central vision and fundoscopic findings of a subretinal haemorrhage and greyish-green retinal discolouration, are characteristic of wet age-related macular degeneration. Ranibizumab is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor .

Highyeild:

VEGF release in wet age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD or neovascular AMD) causes the growth of new, friable blood vessels in the choriocapillaris, which are prone to bleeding and leaking.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Cetuximab is an epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibito r that is used in the treatment of stage IV colorectal cancer , and head and neck cancers. It is not used for the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration. Option: B. Etanercept is a tumour necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor that acts as a TNF-α decoy receptor. It is mainly used in the treatment of systemic inflammatory illnesses like rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and ankylosing spondylitis. It has no role in the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration. Option: D. Aldesleukin is a recombinant cytokine that acts as an interleukin-2 (IL-2) analogue. It is used in the immunotherapy of renal cell carcinoma and metastatic melanoma. However, it is not used for the treatment of wet age-related macular degeneration.

Extraedge:

VEGF inhibitors delivered intravitreally are the first-line treatment for wet AMD and have become the mainstay of treatment due to their efficacy and safety profile.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of left-sided visual loss that started 1 hour ago. He describes initially seeing jagged edges, which was followed by abrupt, complete loss of central vision in the left eye. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His blood pressure is 145/89 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the fundoscopic findings is shown. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm this patient's underlying condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carotid artery duplex ultrasonography The fundoscopy shows a pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the fovea. Together with sudden, painless, transient monocular vision, this finding is concerning for central retinal artery occlusion. Causes include embolism (most common), thrombosis, vasculitis, and fibromuscular dysplasia.

Highyeild:

Carotid artery duplex ultrasonography can be used to evaluate for carotid atherosclerosis, a condition that increases the risk of thromboembolism due to the rupture of atherosclerotic plaques, which is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion . This patient has several atherosclerotic risk factors , including advanced age, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus, which make thromboembolism secondary to carotid artery atherosclerosis the most likely cause of his symptoms.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Increased glycated haemoglobin concentrations are seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. This patient has a history of diabetes and is therefore at risk of diabetic retinopathy , a condition that can cause visual impairment and blindness. However, vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is typically bilateral and occurs over the course of many years, as opposed to the abrupt, unilateral vision loss seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in a patient with diabetic retinopathy shows microaneurysms, hard exudates, and macular edema (non-proliferative) or retinal neovascularization and vitreous haemorrhage (proliferative). Option: B. An optic tonometer is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP) . Increased IOP is seen in patients with glaucoma and patients with increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Both of these conditions can lead to visual impairment. In particular, acute, closed-angle glaucoma can cause sudden-onset visual loss . However, it is typically painful and associated with headache and vomiting, none of which is seen in this patient. Direct fundoscopy in patients with increased ICP shows papilledema . Option: D. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is a nonspecific inflammatory marker that can be increased in cases of infection, inflammation, or malignancy. Temporal arteritis can cause a significant elevation in ESR and is a rare etiology of central retinal artery occlusion, the most likely diagnosis in this patient. However, he lacks other symptoms of temporal arteritis ( e.g., headache, jaw claudication, constitutional symptoms). Moreover, a temporal artery biopsy , not ESR, is the gold standard for the diagnosis of temporal arteritis.
